From the Marylaadcr.

The main exception. and almost the only one,
that has been taken by the Opposition presse, to the
Presidents Message, is the omission to press upon
Congress revision Of The tariff Of duties upon i'm
ports. The Report Of the Secretary OF the rreasu-
ry shews that according to the usage in the earliest
days of the Government that subject has been left
to the Secretary Of the Treasury. the only Head Of
a Department who is by law required to make to
Congress an annual exposition Of the concerns pa-
yed under his charge Of hat report it is not our
purpose now to speak we sinai do 50 at greater lei
sure. We only refer to it proof that there has
been no intentions on the part Of the Executive, To
avoid the question.


In regard to the general exception taken to the Mes,
sage, by those who find no other fault in it. than
that the President has not reiterated his former
commendaons Of several objects of the first impur
tance TO national interests, and to true national olo
ry. may be remarked, the Message itself refers gen
erav to the Presidents former recolnmendationsa a
Of which upon record ;and that the omission to
repeat those recommendations seems properly attib
'ltable to respect for the discretion with which
Congress is invested and certainly not either to any
change ofopnon in relation these objects on the
part Of the President to any indifference TO the
subjects which he has heretofore pressed upon their
attention.

lamentable instance Of the deplorable effects
(which result from excessive tondness Tor ardent
spirits, occurred on Thursday afternoon, within a
few Yards of our office. An Individual named WM.
ARMsrRoNu, just arrived from West Union, either
from the love OF the liquor or from previous lntoxl-
cation, undertook to drink quart of hskey, which
some unthnking persons had agreed to besow on
.hlm for the purpose and, alter huzzang for JACK
;soN, actually contryed to swallow about three half
pints in the course of few minutes As might nat
urally be expected; the wretched man, who
had come to this place for the purpose, as we un-
.derstand, of teaching school, breahed his last
.;bout dusk the same evening, III spite OF every ex
ertion which was made for his recovery. Three
or four individuals were taken up the next mornns
on suspicion Of having, by the dnt OF threats, Undue
ed him to swallow the poisonous liquid; but aite
having undergone an examination before the Mayor
they were all discharged with the exception Of one
who has been recognized to appear at the next tern
of our Court Of Common Pleas, to answer for thi
novel offence
From The Seioto Gazette, Dee. 6.

+ We are pleased 10 learn, from several Of our
members OF the General Assembly, that plans are
forming, in different sections of the State, by our
intelligent farmers for considerably increasing their
ilocks o Sheep and also TOR establishing cotton aud
woollcn manufactures, as the most likely means OF
relieving themselves from the pressure which they
have for some time experienced from the depressed
prices Of every agricultural product. They are
now convinced that those Of sister States whose
citizens are partly engaged in manufacture and COM
nerce, succeed much better in providing the neces-
sares and comforts of life for themselves and fam-
lies, than they able to do from agriculture alone,
and have therefore, wisely come to the dcteimlna-
ton of following their example, possessing, as they
do, equal II not superior. advantages, both Tor ras-
ing sheep and carrying on manufactures. The ad-
viAages which they have for raising sheep arc, the
cheapness Of our lands and the shortness OF our
winters. In the Northern States, lands suitable ior
The purpose OF supporting these animals, cannot,
we pres aue, be purchased Tor less than ten dollars
an acre here It can be had for one dollar In


The New England States, farmers have to feed their
sheep four or live months in the year here not
more than as many weeks Our advantages for en-
gaging in manufactures are equally great. We have
water power 10 any extent which would be requir-
ed, ami the material at our doors and we
heard gentleman state, few days ago, who had
visited the Northern manufacturers with a view to
obtaining information the subject, that III working
cotton mandatory Of 1000 splndes, i'll this State
by means of slave labor for period Of ten years,
there would be a saving of $4,000, in this article


of labor alone, when compared with the cost Of


working the same at the North, besides saving


about -3 cents pound on all the cotton used dur


ing that period.


The great difficulty in raising sheep in this conn


try, heretofore, has been, TO preserve them from


being destroyed by dogs. But this danger will nov


be abolished, by keeping large focks, and employ


ing shepherds to watch over rthem.


How much preferable would course Of thi


kind be to culvatlng jealous, discontented sp'rl
towards our more industrious and enterprlsng brc
; thren OF the North and how much more honorabl
: and useful TO our State
From The Rale,gh ". CD Register,

su,x.--The confidence which we feel that the ma
nuiacture Of silk will ere long prove common and
valuable in this country, induces US to notice every
ding connected with its progress, and we are happy
TO learn from the Courier that at late meeting ofhe
New York Branch of the Linnean Society, Dr.
pascas communicated the introduction and divi-
sion Of his work on the growth and culture Of silk.
The doctors treatise embraces not only the old and
natural method Of rearing silk-worms, but also the
latest improved artificial system by which the crops
himself the solution Of great problem, by proving
that the silk-worm is perfectly electrical insect
and and can be managed und r this datum without much
fear of failure SO as to obtain its valuable produce.
The subject is one Of great Importance and we
look with interest to the completion and publication
of the Doctors treatise, confident that II will con-


tain curious and valuable information in relation to
it's subject. ~. Y. ,Saiesn3ah

Dear Sir,


You love your country. and desire the welfare Of

though you gain no present office. you will receive

oifce, like successive waves shall hava ,nada the;
noise and passed away. ''''A0 ''e''


address what have to say to uou Sir. becouse

~ hs You go to the Capital to promote the public

Extract TO the Edltor--tiated


WASHINGTON, Dec. i5 1921 ?


arrived here few hours after left you in the
morning, and my first essay has been to make my
way lothe Capitol. putup at adsby's new house,
and though very good and spacious one, it suffers
greatly III comparison with Barnun's City Hotel.


With regard to the ruuour started ina Philadel-
phia jackson paper about MIR. Clay's mission to
England, ii is regarded as all moonshinc here and
without pretending to know the secrets of the Exc
cutlve, feel no hesitation in saying the runour is
utterly untounded There will be- no doubt, some
dhculty in making selection.


am happy to find our friends here full Of conf
dence IN success, believing the arch leader of the
Opposition has done his utmost in his tricks of in
trsue and management of his troops. The Mes
sage Of the President has fell upon the Opposition
like a clap of thundrr--it is acknowledged on all
hands to be powerful and lautless--the Opposition
cannot gel hold Of it, SO they arc obliged either to
praise or be silent. Their views on mauy nipor-
tant subjects differ at least as widely from each 9TH
eras from us and it is very far from being in their
power to restrain individuals who may chuse to start
= project, however wild and offensive to many Of
them. This must always he the case with "com-
binaon as Mr.. Floyd Of Virginia termed it, made
up o lhe most Heterogeneous materials, with as ma
ny party hues as there Colors in Josepis coat.
-Hr. baihour, you know, was formerly the Speaker,
but not being willing TO othe whole hog as the
Jacksones have It. they would not permit him ag;n
10 he elevated to that high station His proposition
relative to the sale OF the Bank Stock, Caused as
great Inter among the combination as voIey
OF shot among flock oipigeous. Rely upon il that
some OF the knowing ones amongst them feel much
alarm, and already begin TO look and feel as though
their days are numbered.


At dinner to-day had very free conversation
with two Intelligent Nirpinians--they assured me
that the Jackson fever is burning ont fst-that the
Old Dominion has at last got her thinking cap on ant
that the tide Of public opinion there is turning fast
| in favor OF our present Administration. The vir
tuous Madison Is With US, which cannot fail to have
ITS effect upon the moral sense of mankind. | fine
many well disposed citizens who have been ayerse
TO Mr. Adams. think he has been very harshly ant
very nntarly dealt BY, and viii now give him thcil
support There is evidently calm but sure re.ac
tlon in his favor since the PRONUNCIATION of his las
'ies.lg" Such a long tried, faithful public seryan
'''h 10. ~ ','t'r'i ont Of office for no fa"lt
especially wiien recollection for four short year
viii close hls political life forever.
From the Baltimore Patriot.
Extract to the Edtor.-hated

There is not a more false, Il more erroneous,


more ridiculous simle used, than that which likens


Gen jackson to General Washington. The illus.


trous services The latter in the field and the cah


met, his good sense, his entire devotion 10 the pros


pery OF his country and his regard for its cohsti-


tuition and laws, are qualities in which Gen. Jack
son is dsparagingy deficient. Jackson boasts of


single victory gained at n ewOrleans but its spen.


dor is diminished by the arbitrary acts of which he
was guilty during and after the achievement. Lis
services lawyer and statesman diminish TO al
most an atom. compared with the assidnous and al |
most nnumerablc and various engagements in which
Washington employed his busy mind. Washing
toms free and complete submission to the authority
Of the constitution his open ayowal of its sovereign.
ty and the sanctity of its spirit, all meet with ihe
most striking contradiction in the character and


duct of Gen. jackson. The contracted circle Of
Jacksons same previous TO the battle Of New-Or-


leans-his resignation Of all his civil Offices pre-


dcated on his acknowledged inability to perform the


dues,--the dormancy Of his talents at the most l-


muuous crisis, and his flight from the political con-


test, are facts which destroy all comparison, and


dispaIage both the patriotism and the genius Of the


General. But why should his friends draw such an


inappropriate parallel when the vote OF Jackson


expressed and recorded in lT0G denies the proprie


ity Of chusing Washington example. In con.


sequence of the delivery of the valedctory address


lot Gen. Washington, 81 resolution was adopted


that respectable address ought TO be presented to
the President in answer to his speech-and NlessTs


Anes Baldwin, Madison, Sgrleves and Smith were
, appointed a committee to draw up the address


This address conceded with the sentiments express


ed by Washington, lauded his services, and prayed


the benedictions Of heaven on the remainder OF his
, days. Embodied in the address was the following
g For our country's sake for the sake Of Republl-


can liberty, it is our earnest wish that your fTampe
r mag be the guide ot yoar SUCCESSORS 6c F" motion


was made Tor the expunging OF this, and supported
j by remarks as disgraceul to the speaker they
! were stigmatZing to the character of Washington.


On the vote favorable for expungng the above clause


stands recorded, to his eternal disgrace, the vote Oi
. ANDREW JACKSON. Then can that comparison
A be true. which kens Jackson to Washington ? Car


be agreeable TO the principles and wishes Of
s Jackson himself, when he was opposed TO chusIs
d the Father Of his country as an 8 example"


), But while we would thus show the talsity Of such
IT a smile, we woad wish the community to consider,
j. how they would enfianger the peace, reputation
and prosperity of their country, by supporting the
J. preensons of one whose principles and acts would
l., be different from those of President Washington.
Was there ever a man who better understood the
e interests ofthc Union? Wasthere ever man whose
r conduct congenial with the wishes OF the
People No, never: and he who would dscredit his
services, disapproye Of his acts and pursue policy
different from, or opposed to his, deserves not the
d appreciation or support OF his fellow citizens. Ant
e. such man is General Jackson. R.

Since the friends Of the Administration have be-
gan to Stir themselves. the opposition in this State
have ceased to boast OF their strength. The meet
ings held in the different counties, within a few
weeks past, have been so unmcrously and rcspecta


bly, attended. as to show that diversity of opinion
on the next Presidency, scarcely exists among us ;
and that, when the day Of trial shall come, the free
men oiOhio will give :" long pull a strong pull,
and pull altogether, in favor of an Administra-
tion which watches over, protects and promotes
the real interests. by all constitutional means. Our
limits will not permit us to record the proceedings
Of all the meetings which may take place but we
shall endeayor to find room for those held in the
counties IN which our journal circulatas, If forward


cd to Us for that purpose. Those Of which an ac


count is given in this days paper, we arc told b,
gentlemen present, were Of the most respectable


characters and it is now expected that Pickawa,
[ rom tic Ohio G a-ette.

Not having much to do, Tor lew moments, we
will just serve up another bitter draught for the
plant editor OF the Argus, as yet he has not at
empted to justify the crooked course he has pur.
sued. 1t is well that he is silent for any attempt
to justify his agitous acts would but sink him deep
er in political degradation. and public contempt Tor
the prostitution Of the little talents with which he
has been endowed, in yielding himself implicitly to
the dictatlon of men without principle. In his pa
per Of the l4th May, 1924. in speaking Of the pre-
tensions Of General Jackson. he represents him as
one :. WHOSE AalBI ZION IS AS INSATlA,
BILE AS THE SEA. AND WHO 70 GRAFT
Fly HIS lNORDINATE LUST OF POWER
WOULD OVERLEAP ALL BOUNDS" Bu
now. fursooth, he is represented as the very lamb 0
mcekncss. and the very paragon Of republican purl
ty. Will the Argus be kind enough TO inform
the public when the change took place ?


Was there ever earth such treachery, snc
abandonment of principle as is evidenced in tn
present actious course of the Argus, and SOM
half dozen of the combination prints, contrast
ed by their former professions and we'll known pre-
sent opinions? This is, indeed, :. the madness c
party"

From the baltimore .Anleyican.


The English intelligence received by the packet
ship William Byrnes, which is to the Sth Of Nov
presents decided change in the relations ot Euro
pean affairs. ihe final intentions Of the Porte ap
pear as uncertain as ever and though no doubt a
great part Of the rumours to which the events OF
the day are continually giving rise, are either idle
conjectures gotten up for stock jobbng purposes,
the better opinion seems to be, that European at
fairs must be considered in quite an unsettled state.
The silence OF Austria, in c0nnexlon with her pro-
cedures in the I4evan. certainly affords ground for
suspicion that she is net ready to take part with the
Allies, especially when is considered that the re-
suit Of any successful attack on the Ottoman pow
er, will be TO give prepondcrating advantages to
Russia. The silence and protracted delay OF the
Porte. are equally expainabe on two grounds. r.
ven if she concession necessary in the end. it
would be natural in her to tempori1e. and postpone,
at least. this nvasion as she must conceive it, her
rights of sovereignty. If resolved on war, the de-
lay would be equally desirable. both to postpone the
actual evil, and take measures for breaking its force
when it comes, as much as possible.


tgliacss Ordinary persons, pcradventure, may
not have remarked (what may prove comfort to
them) that true ugliness is almost as rare a Gift as
true beauty for how very few ll-Avored viaages do
We encounter that possess not some redeenng lea-

and a prompter TO the emulation Of goodness. And

boyhood, well remember young man (whom |

ordinary young man. both as respects his lineaments
and his learning. He was deep read--pae-
by the small -poX-pited by every female who be.
held him. But he had mind that minded not
their impertnent commlseration and when his con.
versationa talents began gradually to be developed
by the genial influence Of social conyerse--his an
posite remarks, his critical reading, and sound argu
ments won all the listening senses of his auditors


while lnslpd beauty was lost in the fluent language
of eloquent usness. The s.pveffy naca'' of the par
ty felt the unintellighle deserton of the fair ones


and glanced cautiously round at their sweet persons
reflected In the mirrors, as they ounged stlessl,
about imagining that some alarming revolution hat
taken place in their collars cravats. or some re
belious lock had stretched itself ungraceuy fortl
from their closc-curled Roman crops. or pooaies-
then finding all III statu qao. wildly wondered
''what the girls could possibly see in the fellow Il
pay him so much attention 70 while others lispet
forth in voice half strangled by their stocks, !.


s'pose the bellies are quizzing the Gorgon !" IJgli
ness hath charms that pass not away like the bloom
of summer flower, r,-thelelore, let not ueliness b,
put out of conceit If there be but wit and goot
sense behind the repusiyc mask. ugliness may wi,
the Earour and co,.oto,-.-~o nc oeauty. Eng. pap

LrBERIA.-'Ihe Norfolk IIeral,l.-on the authori


ty of Dir. Tudsrn. who has Just arrived from Ii


IBERIA, communicates the gratifying ntelisenc,


that the Colony was in very thriving cundi


ton, the people enjoying good health, and bein.


not only contentet but delighted with their new


home. The trade at the Cape was very prosperous


and daily extending itself; some of the settlers ha,
accumulated handsome fortunes, and all were ia
beyond the reach Of want; nay indulging them
selves with many of the uxuries and elegancies d
fashionable life: and new houses were continual
in the progress Of building. Nor was the necessit
Of dfusing education overlooked for DR.. r. state
that so careful had the coonists been in this respect
that all their children of sufficient age could at eas
5 read and write The attachment of the people a
the Cape. to trade and commerce, had caused then
e to neglect agriculture in some degree but that i'm
/ portant interest was successfully followed up
: the settlement of St. Paul's about or miles dis
y tant.-in SHIRT from the account given by Dr. 4
e the colony bids fair to infinitely moretlan realis
y the most sanguine expectations Of its tounders.

ports. The Report Of the Secretary OF the rreasu-
ry shews that according to the usage in the earliest
days of the Government that subject has been left
to the Secretary Of the Treasury. the only Head Of
a Department who is by law required to make to
Congress an annual exposition Of the concerns pa-
yed under his charge Of hat report it is not our
purpose now to speak we sinai do 50 at greater lei
sure. We only refer to it proof that there has
been no intentions on the part Of the Executive, To
avoid the question.

that the President has not reiterated his former
commendaons Of several objects of the first impur
tance TO national interests, and to true national olo
ry. may be remarked, the Message itself refers gen
erav to the Presidents former recolnmendationsa a
Of which upon record ;and that the omission to
repeat those recommendations seems properly attib

Congress is invested and certainly not either to any
change ofopnon in relation these objects on the
part Of the President to any indifference TO the
subjects which he has heretofore pressed upon their
attention.

The British ministers enterlainno apprehension ina
the intelligence from Nayarino will reach the lur
kish government before il is received Blythe amhas
sadors,; this we hope, for the sake o humanity
will prove to he the case, for the first ebull.tion

full articles.headline: From The Seioto Gazette, Dee. 6.
full articles.article:
lamentable instance Of the deplorable effects
(which result from excessive tondness Tor ardent
spirits, occurred on Thursday afternoon, within a
few Yards of our office. An Individual named WM.
ARMsrRoNu, just arrived from West Union, either
from the love OF the liquor or from previous lntoxl-
cation, undertook to drink quart of hskey, which
some unthnking persons had agreed to besow on
.hlm for the purpose and, alter huzzang for JACK
;soN, actually contryed to swallow about three half
pints in the course of few minutes As might nat
urally be expected; the wretched man, who
had come to this place for the purpose, as we un-
.derstand, of teaching school, breahed his last
.;bout dusk the same evening, III spite OF every ex
ertion which was made for his recovery. Three
or four individuals were taken up the next mornns
on suspicion Of having, by the dnt OF threats, Undue
ed him to swallow the poisonous liquid; but aite
having undergone an examination before the Mayor
they were all discharged with the exception Of one
who has been recognized to appear at the next tern
of our Court Of Common Pleas, to answer for thi
novel offence

full articles.headline: From The Rale,gh ". CD Register,
full articles.article:
+ We are pleased 10 learn, from several Of our
members OF the General Assembly, that plans are
forming, in different sections of the State, by our
intelligent farmers for considerably increasing their
ilocks o Sheep and also TOR establishing cotton aud
woollcn manufactures, as the most likely means OF
relieving themselves from the pressure which they
have for some time experienced from the depressed
prices Of every agricultural product. They are
now convinced that those Of sister States whose
citizens are partly engaged in manufacture and COM
nerce, succeed much better in providing the neces-
sares and comforts of life for themselves and fam-
lies, than they able to do from agriculture alone,
and have therefore, wisely come to the dcteimlna-
ton of following their example, possessing, as they
do, equal II not superior. advantages, both Tor ras-
ing sheep and carrying on manufactures. The ad-
viAages which they have for raising sheep arc, the
cheapness Of our lands and the shortness OF our
winters. In the Northern States, lands suitable ior
The purpose OF supporting these animals, cannot,
we pres aue, be purchased Tor less than ten dollars
an acre here It can be had for one dollar In


The New England States, farmers have to feed their
sheep four or live months in the year here not
more than as many weeks Our advantages for en-
gaging in manufactures are equally great. We have
water power 10 any extent which would be requir-
ed, ami the material at our doors and we
heard gentleman state, few days ago, who had
visited the Northern manufacturers with a view to
obtaining information the subject, that III working
cotton mandatory Of 1000 splndes, i'll this State
by means of slave labor for period Of ten years,
there would be a saving of $4,000, in this article


of labor alone, when compared with the cost Of


working the same at the North, besides saving


about -3 cents pound on all the cotton used dur


ing that period.


The great difficulty in raising sheep in this conn


try, heretofore, has been, TO preserve them from


being destroyed by dogs. But this danger will nov


be abolished, by keeping large focks, and employ


ing shepherds to watch over rthem.


How much preferable would course Of thi


kind be to culvatlng jealous, discontented sp'rl
towards our more industrious and enterprlsng brc
; thren OF the North and how much more honorabl
: and useful TO our State

su,x.--The confidence which we feel that the ma
nuiacture Of silk will ere long prove common and
valuable in this country, induces US to notice every
ding connected with its progress, and we are happy
TO learn from the Courier that at late meeting ofhe
New York Branch of the Linnean Society, Dr.
pascas communicated the introduction and divi-
sion Of his work on the growth and culture Of silk.
The doctors treatise embraces not only the old and
natural method Of rearing silk-worms, but also the
latest improved artificial system by which the crops
himself the solution Of great problem, by proving
that the silk-worm is perfectly electrical insect
and and can be managed und r this datum without much
fear of failure SO as to obtain its valuable produce.
The subject is one Of great Importance and we
look with interest to the completion and publication
of the Doctors treatise, confident that II will con-


tain curious and valuable information in relation to
it's subject. ~. Y. ,Saiesn3ah

LETTER |.


Dear Sir,


You love your country. and desire the welfare Of

though you gain no present office. you will receive
the thanks OF a grateful community, the blessings
ofa benefited posterity, and by which YOU will be
doing good, when the political squabbles whether
John or jonathan. Quincy or Andrew shall have an
oifce, like successive waves shall hava ,nada the;
noise and passed away. ''''A0 ''e''


address what have to say to uou Sir. becouse

go 70 Dover to practice political maneuvers and in

.'a, me dying cries of Revolutionary veterans arc
N the ears of political intriguers at WASHINGTON.
~ hs You go to the Capital to promote the public
sooa'o increase the prosperity ufthe State on whose
interests you are called to deliberate, LET me eary
esly' yet respectfully, recommend measure, By

full articles.headline:
From the Baltimore Patriot.

Extract to the Edtor.-hated
full articles.article:
Extract TO the Edltor--tiated


WASHINGTON, Dec. i5 1921 ?


arrived here few hours after left you in the
morning, and my first essay has been to make my
way lothe Capitol. putup at adsby's new house,
and though very good and spacious one, it suffers
greatly III comparison with Barnun's City Hotel.


With regard to the ruuour started ina Philadel-
phia jackson paper about MIR. Clay's mission to
England, ii is regarded as all moonshinc here and
without pretending to know the secrets of the Exc
cutlve, feel no hesitation in saying the runour is
utterly untounded There will be- no doubt, some
dhculty in making selection.


am happy to find our friends here full Of conf
dence IN success, believing the arch leader of the
Opposition has done his utmost in his tricks of in
trsue and management of his troops. The Mes
sage Of the President has fell upon the Opposition
like a clap of thundrr--it is acknowledged on all
hands to be powerful and lautless--the Opposition
cannot gel hold Of it, SO they arc obliged either to
praise or be silent. Their views on mauy nipor-
tant subjects differ at least as widely from each 9TH
eras from us and it is very far from being in their
power to restrain individuals who may chuse to start
= project, however wild and offensive to many Of
them. This must always he the case with "com-
binaon as Mr.. Floyd Of Virginia termed it, made
up o lhe most Heterogeneous materials, with as ma
ny party hues as there Colors in Josepis coat.
-Hr. baihour, you know, was formerly the Speaker,
but not being willing TO othe whole hog as the
Jacksones have It. they would not permit him ag;n
10 he elevated to that high station His proposition
relative to the sale OF the Bank Stock, Caused as
great Inter among the combination as voIey
OF shot among flock oipigeous. Rely upon il that
some OF the knowing ones amongst them feel much
alarm, and already begin TO look and feel as though
their days are numbered.


At dinner to-day had very free conversation
with two Intelligent Nirpinians--they assured me
that the Jackson fever is burning ont fst-that the
Old Dominion has at last got her thinking cap on ant
that the tide Of public opinion there is turning fast
| in favor OF our present Administration. The vir
tuous Madison Is With US, which cannot fail to have
ITS effect upon the moral sense of mankind. | fine
many well disposed citizens who have been ayerse
TO Mr. Adams. think he has been very harshly ant
very nntarly dealt BY, and viii now give him thcil
support There is evidently calm but sure re.ac
tlon in his favor since the PRONUNCIATION of his las
'ies.lg" Such a long tried, faithful public seryan
'''h 10. ~ ','t'r'i ont Of office for no fa"lt
especially wiien recollection for four short year
viii close hls political life forever.

full articles.article:
There is not a more false, Il more erroneous,


more ridiculous simle used, than that which likens


Gen jackson to General Washington. The illus.


trous services The latter in the field and the cah


met, his good sense, his entire devotion 10 the pros


pery OF his country and his regard for its cohsti-


tuition and laws, are qualities in which Gen. Jack
son is dsparagingy deficient. Jackson boasts of


single victory gained at n ewOrleans but its spen.


dor is diminished by the arbitrary acts of which he
was guilty during and after the achievement. Lis
services lawyer and statesman diminish TO al
most an atom. compared with the assidnous and al |
most nnumerablc and various engagements in which
Washington employed his busy mind. Washing
toms free and complete submission to the authority
Of the constitution his open ayowal of its sovereign.
ty and the sanctity of its spirit, all meet with ihe
most striking contradiction in the character and


duct of Gen. jackson. The contracted circle Of
Jacksons same previous TO the battle Of New-Or-


leans-his resignation Of all his civil Offices pre-


dcated on his acknowledged inability to perform the


dues,--the dormancy Of his talents at the most l-


muuous crisis, and his flight from the political con-


test, are facts which destroy all comparison, and


dispaIage both the patriotism and the genius Of the


General. But why should his friends draw such an


inappropriate parallel when the vote OF Jackson


expressed and recorded in lT0G denies the proprie


ity Of chusing Washington example. In con.


sequence of the delivery of the valedctory address


lot Gen. Washington, 81 resolution was adopted


that respectable address ought TO be presented to
the President in answer to his speech-and NlessTs


Anes Baldwin, Madison, Sgrleves and Smith were
, appointed a committee to draw up the address


This address conceded with the sentiments express


ed by Washington, lauded his services, and prayed


the benedictions Of heaven on the remainder OF his
, days. Embodied in the address was the following
g For our country's sake for the sake Of Republl-


can liberty, it is our earnest wish that your fTampe
r mag be the guide ot yoar SUCCESSORS 6c F" motion


was made Tor the expunging OF this, and supported
j by remarks as disgraceul to the speaker they
! were stigmatZing to the character of Washington.


On the vote favorable for expungng the above clause


stands recorded, to his eternal disgrace, the vote Oi
. ANDREW JACKSON. Then can that comparison
A be true. which kens Jackson to Washington ? Car


be agreeable TO the principles and wishes Of
s Jackson himself, when he was opposed TO chusIs
d the Father Of his country as an 8 example"


), But while we would thus show the talsity Of such
IT a smile, we woad wish the community to consider,
j. how they would enfianger the peace, reputation
and prosperity of their country, by supporting the
J. preensons of one whose principles and acts would
l., be different from those of President Washington.
Was there ever a man who better understood the
e interests ofthc Union? Wasthere ever man whose
r conduct congenial with the wishes OF the
People No, never: and he who would dscredit his
services, disapproye Of his acts and pursue policy
different from, or opposed to his, deserves not the
d appreciation or support OF his fellow citizens. Ant
e. such man is General Jackson. R.

full articles.headline: [ rom tic Ohio G a-ette.
full articles.article:
Since the friends Of the Administration have be-
gan to Stir themselves. the opposition in this State
have ceased to boast OF their strength. The meet
ings held in the different counties, within a few
weeks past, have been so unmcrously and rcspecta


bly, attended. as to show that diversity of opinion
on the next Presidency, scarcely exists among us ;
and that, when the day Of trial shall come, the free
men oiOhio will give :" long pull a strong pull,
and pull altogether, in favor of an Administra-
tion which watches over, protects and promotes
the real interests. by all constitutional means. Our
limits will not permit us to record the proceedings
Of all the meetings which may take place but we
shall endeayor to find room for those held in the
counties IN which our journal circulatas, If forward


cd to Us for that purpose. Those Of which an ac


count is given in this days paper, we arc told b,
gentlemen present, were Of the most respectable


characters and it is now expected that Pickawa,

full articles.headline: From, Tie .4lbanu Duilu .Aduertiser.
full articles.article:
Not having much to do, Tor lew moments, we
will just serve up another bitter draught for the
plant editor OF the Argus, as yet he has not at
empted to justify the crooked course he has pur.
sued. 1t is well that he is silent for any attempt
to justify his agitous acts would but sink him deep
er in political degradation. and public contempt Tor
the prostitution Of the little talents with which he
has been endowed, in yielding himself implicitly to
the dictatlon of men without principle. In his pa
per Of the l4th May, 1924. in speaking Of the pre-
tensions Of General Jackson. he represents him as
one :. WHOSE AalBI ZION IS AS INSATlA,
BILE AS THE SEA. AND WHO 70 GRAFT
Fly HIS lNORDINATE LUST OF POWER
WOULD OVERLEAP ALL BOUNDS" Bu
now. fursooth, he is represented as the very lamb 0
mcekncss. and the very paragon Of republican purl
ty. Will the Argus be kind enough TO inform
the public when the change took place ?


Was there ever earth such treachery, snc
abandonment of principle as is evidenced in tn
present actious course of the Argus, and SOM
half dozen of the combination prints, contrast
ed by their former professions and we'll known pre-
sent opinions? This is, indeed, :. the madness c
party"

full articles.headline: From the baltimore Ameyican.
full articles.article:
From the baltimore .Anleyican.


The English intelligence received by the packet
ship William Byrnes, which is to the Sth Of Nov
presents decided change in the relations ot Euro
pean affairs. ihe final intentions Of the Porte ap
pear as uncertain as ever and though no doubt a
great part Of the rumours to which the events OF
the day are continually giving rise, are either idle
conjectures gotten up for stock jobbng purposes,
the better opinion seems to be, that European at
fairs must be considered in quite an unsettled state.
The silence OF Austria, in c0nnexlon with her pro-
cedures in the I4evan. certainly affords ground for
suspicion that she is net ready to take part with the
Allies, especially when is considered that the re-
suit Of any successful attack on the Ottoman pow
er, will be TO give prepondcrating advantages to
Russia. The silence and protracted delay OF the
Porte. are equally expainabe on two grounds. r.
ven if she concession necessary in the end. it
would be natural in her to tempori1e. and postpone,
at least. this nvasion as she must conceive it, her
rights of sovereignty. If resolved on war, the de-
lay would be equally desirable. both to postpone the
actual evil, and take measures for breaking its force
when it comes, as much as possible.


tgliacss Ordinary persons, pcradventure, may
not have remarked (what may prove comfort to
them) that true ugliness is almost as rare a Gift as
true beauty for how very few ll-Avored viaages do
We encounter that possess not some redeenng lea-

OF the lavish bounty OF nature, uglness may vauDt of
her plum dealing. | am far from regarding ugli-
ness in woman as unlo rtunate rather consider
it as an antidote to vanity, safeguard to virtue.
and a prompter TO the emulation Of goodness. And
beauty, after ALL las wrnkIetl old maids and 'shacc
beens" sagely declare.) is but skin deep In my
boyhood, well remember young man (whom |
have often had the pleasure of mcetng) whose phys
ognomcal possessions might certainly be classed
under the title ofugncss in south he was an ertgu
ordinary young man. both as respects his lineaments
and his learning. He was deep read--pae-
by the small -poX-pited by every female who be.
held him. But he had mind that minded not
their impertnent commlseration and when his con.
versationa talents began gradually to be developed
by the genial influence Of social conyerse--his an
posite remarks, his critical reading, and sound argu
ments won all the listening senses of his auditors


while lnslpd beauty was lost in the fluent language
of eloquent usness. The s.pveffy naca'' of the par
ty felt the unintellighle deserton of the fair ones


and glanced cautiously round at their sweet persons
reflected In the mirrors, as they ounged stlessl,
about imagining that some alarming revolution hat
taken place in their collars cravats. or some re
belious lock had stretched itself ungraceuy fortl
from their closc-curled Roman crops. or pooaies-
then finding all III statu qao. wildly wondered
''what the girls could possibly see in the fellow Il
pay him so much attention 70 while others lispet
forth in voice half strangled by their stocks, !.


s'pose the bellies are quizzing the Gorgon !" IJgli
ness hath charms that pass not away like the bloom
of summer flower, r,-thelelore, let not ueliness b,
put out of conceit If there be but wit and goot
sense behind the repusiyc mask. ugliness may wi,
the Earour and co,.oto,-.-~o nc oeauty. Eng. pap
|


LrBERIA.-'Ihe Norfolk IIeral,l.-on the authori


ty of Dir. Tudsrn. who has Just arrived from Ii


IBERIA, communicates the gratifying ntelisenc,


that the Colony was in very thriving cundi


ton, the people enjoying good health, and bein.


not only contentet but delighted with their new


home. The trade at the Cape was very prosperous


and daily extending itself; some of the settlers ha,
accumulated handsome fortunes, and all were ia
beyond the reach Of want; nay indulging them
selves with many of the uxuries and elegancies d
fashionable life: and new houses were continual
in the progress Of building. Nor was the necessit
Of dfusing education overlooked for DR.. r. state
that so careful had the coonists been in this respect
that all their children of sufficient age could at eas
5 read and write The attachment of the people a
the Cape. to trade and commerce, had caused then
e to neglect agriculture in some degree but that i'm
/ portant interest was successfully followed up
: the settlement of St. Paul's about or miles dis
y tant.-in SHIRT from the account given by Dr. 4
e the colony bids fair to infinitely moretlan realis
y the most sanguine expectations Of its tounders.

county, in which the IIeroites have heretofore
